newsitem.title: USA: US corporate bonds end slow day lower,spreads firm.
newsitem.headline: US corporate bonds end slow day lower,spreads firm.

text.p: U.S. high-grade corporate bonds inched steadily lower throughout Wednesday's session to close modestly weaker, along with Treasuries, in thin trade, dealers said.
Junk bonds shed 1/8 to 1/4 of a point, also in soporific trade, despite a tick up in the U.S. equity markets.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended up 8.51 at 5656.90 while the 30-year long bond traded off 13/32 at 95-24/32 to yield 7.09 percent in late trade.
Investment-grade spreads across most maturities were quoted unchanged except that for Continental Cablevision Inc debt, which dealers said tightened two basis points on the long end.
In high-yield, ValuJet Inc notes continued to push higher after news last week the discount airline's fleet will return to the skies in two to three weeks.

ValuJet 10.25 percent paper due 2001 was offered at 88 bid, 89-1/2 offer, up 1/4 from Tuesday's close on the offer side. The paper traded up 3/4 of a point in Tuesday trade after gaining a little over a point last Friday, traders said.
"ValuJet paper has steadily gone up since the news," one high-yield trader said.
In the grocery sector, performance was mixed. Brunos paper lost 1/2 point at 100-1/2 bid while Ralphs Grocery 11.0 percent paper fell 1/8, high-yield traders said.
However, Pathmark Stores 9.625 percent paper traded up 1/2 at 95-1/4 bid and Grand Union paper was unchanged, traders said.
Moving to gaming, Stratosphere Corp's 14.25 percent paper traded up 1/4 at 81-3/4 bid, 82-1/2 offer after gaining 2-1/2 points in Tuesday trade.
Stratosphere notes shed over four points last Friday after news the company suspended construction on its new hotel tower due to an anticipated cash shortfall, dealers said.
The new issue market came back to life Wednesday with two issues pricing after a long hiatus .

Associates Corp of North America, a Ford Motor unit, priced $400 million in two-year notes via lead manager Merrill Lynch & Co. The AA3/AA-minus, 6.50 percent notes were priced at 99.954 to yield 6.525 or 17 basis points over comparable U.S. Treasuries.
Also, Capital One Financial unit Capital One Bank priced $200 million in 10-year, Baa3/BBB- bank notes at 99.953 to yield 7.167 or 60 basis points over the comparable Treasury.
The notes have a three-year put option and are noncallable for life, lead manager JP Morgan Securities Inc said.
Looking ahead, primary and secondary corporate bond activity is seen muted ahead of the critical U.S. employment report due out Friday, dealers added.
In a Reuter poll, U.S. economist predicted an increase of 244,000 in nonfarm payrolls and expect the unemployment rate to dip slightly to 5.3 percent from 5.4 percent.
